newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-BHP iron plant workers stay on strike.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-BHP iron plant workers stay on strike.

text.p: Construction workers building a A$1.5 billion iron plant for The Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd in Port Hedland, Western Australia, on Wednesday rejected a back to work order by a government arbitrator, a BHP spokesman said.
Over 600 workers walked off the job on January 2 over wage and benefit claims.

The workers, belonging to the metals workers, electrical workers and crane drivers' unions are seeking up to 38 percent in additional wages and A$500 a week living-away-from-home allowance to cover the cost of living in far north Western Australia.
A recommendation by the Industrial Relations Commission to go back to work was rejected at a mass meeting on Wednesday, with workers electing to strike indefinitely, the spokesman said.
"We are obviously disappointed over the workers' decision to stay out," he said.
But because the workers are hired by an independent contractor to construct the plant, BHP was powerless to end the dispute, the spokesman said.
The plant is being built to produce hot-briquetted iron pellets, which are used as high-grade substitutes for scrap metal in steelmaking.
It is still due to start up in about a year, the spokesman added.
